newsitem.title: UK: FEATURE - Northern Ireland police back on front line.
newsitem.headline: FEATURE - Northern Ireland police back on front line.

text.p: The haircut was the give-away. Military in length and made for a uniformed cap, it belonged to a Northern Ireland policeman dressed in casual clothes on a shopping trip with his wife in downtown Belfast.
But he refused to recognise the man hailing him, even though, just a day earlier, they had spent some time talking about the province's future when he was uniformed and carrying a gun.
Days after the IRA murdered two of his colleagues, this Northern Ireland policeman, like many in the 12,00-strong force, just wanted to be invisible.

The dead men were the 300th and 301st members of the Royal Ulster Constabulary to be killed in the 28-year Northern Ireland conflict, shot dead in the southern town of Lurgan by IRA hit-men who killed with clinical precision.

The Irish Republican Army (IRA) chose them and their high-profile green uniforms because they represent the British rule the guerrillas are sworn to end and are also mainly Protestants, who want the province to stay British.

Being a policeman or policewoman in Northern Ireland means a well-paid job in an economy with 11 percent unemployment, being a target for guerrillas on both sides of the sectarian divide and, in many cases, having to live in a certain anonymity.
Most police give photographs of their passing out parades pride of place on the mantlepiece or entrance to their homes.
But in Northern Ireland they are hidden in drawers so that no unannounced visitor will ever know that there is a member of the RUC in the house.
Every day they they peer under their cars for booby-trap bombs. Only close neighbours know what their occupation is. The tell-tale green police shirts are rarely on the washing line.
Days after IRA blew holes in a peace process, the RUC is back on the front-line of a growing guerrilla war.
POLICE ARE THE IRA'S MAIN TARGET
Throughtout the conflict, the RUC and British troops who guard their patrols have been the IRA's chief target in country lanes, at town checkpoints and even city centres.

For 17 brief months of an IRA truce they abandoned their customary flak jackets and automatic rifles and went after what they call ODC's - Ordinary Decent Criminals - and, residents say, had an unprecedented purge on speeding motorists.
But that honeymoon ended when the IRA ended its truce in February last year with the bombing of London's Canary Wharf complex which killed two and reignited the conflict.
"When the Canary Wharf bomb went off, my heart sank. I thought to myself 'we're on a slide. It's starting again'," recalled a veteran officer, who asked not to be named.
He had seen at first hand the depths of a 1969-1994 IRA guerrilla war that erupted in daylight on street corners or along darked country lanes in a conflict that killed 3,200.
Officers torn apart by guerrilla rockets. Bewildered parents being led into hospitals to identify loved ones found bound, gagged and shot, victims of sectarian murder gangs.
IRA TOLD TO TARGET SECURITY FORCES

A senior British security source said IRA "volunteers" have been told by their commanders to attack Northern Ireland soldiers and police officers, preferably while on duty and in uniform, in an escalation of a war to end British rule. "The threat is high against security forces right across the province," the source told Reuters.
"The IRA is quite well supplied. Alongside all their commercially-produced weaponry, they have also always relied heavily on home-made weapons which are just effective."
The Lurgan IRA murders were the first of police officers since the IRA ceasefire ended and marked a return of the guerrillas to their Northern Ireland battleground after months of relative calm.

The killings took place weeks before the annual "marching season" by Protestants takes place, a flashpoint period which last year descended into the worst civil strife the province has seen for decades.

In July last year police chiefs banned a traditional march from a church at Drumcree through the Catholic Carvaghy area of the southern town of Portadown because Catholics objected and said the march amounted to intimidation.
The ban was lifted after Protestants paralysed the province with riots, road blocks and fires. The march went ahead, triggering days of Catholic rioting instead.
Throughout the men and women of the RUC were targets for both sides. "We know where you live, we know where your houses are," Protestant extremists taunted police who blocked their path at Drumcree.
In Londonderry, a Catholic stronghold, police were showered with hundreds of petrol bombs, rocks and missiles in an explosion of anger that took thousands of police and days to douse.

Distrusted by sections of Catholics and regarded by many Protestants as a bulwark for preserving treasured British links, RUC officers say they have been pitched into a no-win position in the middle of age-old rivalries.
"We get it from both sides. We're caught in the middle of this. We're marked men, whatever we do," said the police officer who preferred not to be recognised while shopping in Belfast.
It is a normal precaution. Children are gently reminded not to leave doors open and to not to talk too much about "what dad does".

"You try to strike a balance between not being careless and being alive to the fact that there are people who would maybe go to your house and plant a bomb under your car or shoot at your home," a long-serving officer said.
